turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you said several times, this is the maritime tort.
Do we have to face on that to determine the principal jurisdiction on the Norris-LaGuardia Act?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, there was no claim made until a petition for rehearing below that there wasn't a -- a tort here, if Norris-LaGuardia didn't protect the conduct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where are the -- the question I asked was whether we have to think about that at all in connection with determining whether this -- under the Norris-LaGuardia Act.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor.
I -- I think that they haven't really challenged that there is.
We've cited some cases on our brief that show that this is a -- a -- that interference with maritime contractual relation is a maritime tort.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not sure that if it -- it --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- it isn't impertinent to intervene.
I'm not sure that you get the whole force of Justice Black's question.

If we determine -- if the Court determines this is a limitation upon the courts not to issue an injunction in labor controversy on the Norris-LaGuardia Act applies to this, we don't have to bother what the nature of the suit is, don't we?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Your Honor's question is whether --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you have the question?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Yes.
In other words, if -- if you apply that the -- if you determine that the Norris-LaGuardia Act applies, well, then clearly, the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If they remanded the litigation as to --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Well, the injunctive relief has clearly ended and I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But all we have here --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: The suit was for damages as well.
But at the present time, the only thing on appeal is the injunction, so your --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: -- the Court would not necessarily reach the other question.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But isn't that true?
Isn't that all there is before us now?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: The injunction, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The injunction.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If your answer to Justice Black is, yes, then isn't it?
If Norris LaGuardia limits the Court in -- as to this litigation, it's an end of it, so far as we're concerned.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: You would reverse the judgement below and remand, I don't think you would direct the dismissal of the complaint.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Do you not, is that quite correct?
Would you not have to first be in the court that had power to hear before the Norris-LaGuardia question prohibiting injunctions in special cases would arise?
So don't you have to show a fundamental basis of jurisdiction in the court before you get to the Norris-LaGuardia question?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think we have two burdens.
We have to show fundamental jurisdiction and we have to show that there is no labor dispute.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: If -- if you resolve either of those questions against this, I suppose it -- it terminates the case against us --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: -- to that extent.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But my point is that before we can get to the Norris-LaGuardia question, do we not have to find that there was -- there would be jurisdiction otherwise?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: I think that the normal method by which the Court proceeds is to first consider basic jurisdiction, but I don't suppose there's anything that requires that and if the Court wanted to say, we don't have to consider basic jurisdiction, there wouldn't have been a right to issue an injunction here anyway.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, then --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: It could reverse on that ground.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) wouldn't the normal thing, in this case, be to deal with that problem of jurisdiction which is conclusive no matter what?
If the Norris-LaGuardia Act is conclusive no matter what, why bother whether it refers to find that we have jurisdiction on some other ground?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: I think either question of jurisdiction could be conclusive no matter what if you decided it against us.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes but -- [Laughter] it -- it maybe conclusive.
Yes, but if -- if Norris-LaGuardia does apply, then it must be conclusive.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, the Court Of Appeals here has granted an injunction.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: The Court of Appeals has affirmed to grant up an injunction by the District Court.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, then, for you to keep that judgement and getting affirmance, if the questions so feel, you'll have to show, would you not, both basic jurisdiction and non-applicability of Norris-LaGuardia?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Certainly, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: So then do you not have to sustain here both burdens --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- if you -- if you're to win?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: That's right

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now then, what's the basis of your jurisdiction, your fundamental jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: I think there are -- there are several alternative bases, Mr. Justice Whittaker.
There is a basis of jurisdiction under 1331 and 1350 because of treaty rights.
There is a jurisdiction under 1333 because of maritime rights and we claim that admiralty has the power to issue an injunction.
If admiralty has not the power to issue an injunction, there is a basis under 1331 because of the substantive maritime law applied and no adequate alternative remedy in admiralty.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And everyone of your hypotheses includes the assumption that this is a “maritime claim” as contemplated within the meaning of Footnote 23 of this Court's opinion in the Romero case.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: I don't think the rights under 1331 and 1350 which are based on treaty rights necessarily involved the maritime nature of the case, so I think the -- that certainly the rights under 1333 or the right under 1331, because of maritime tort depends upon that exception.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: The Court was at pains in this Footnote 23 to point out, that all suits involving maritime claims regardless of the remedies sought, our case is in admiralty and maritime jurisdiction, but they first have to be maritime claims.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Can you say this is --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: Certainly, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you can't get to it, can you, unless if the Norris-LaGuardia Act bargained.
You never have to -- we have that reset (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: That's right.
You can start with either jurisdictional question.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you don't have through (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: I hope you will reach both of them and -- and resolve from both in favor of the respondents --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_d_mosser
turn.label: Mr. John D. Mosser
turn.text: -- and affirm the judgement below.
Thank you

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Jennings.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, if Your Honors please.
I would like to clarify one matter which is in nature of its dispute that we have here.
We have issued all intent to interfere anyway with the internal economy of this ship.
We realize because of this Court's decision in the Benz case and we could not represent or seek to represent these foreign seamen or to bargain for them.
The position of the union is best expressed in the picket sign which was used on board the Willoughby, as it circled the Nikolos.
The AFL-CIO seamen protest loss of their employment, because of the use of foreign flagships employing seamen at substandard wages.
That was the nature of the protest.
The dispute could have been settled in a variety of ways.

The record indicates that Mr. Schultz, who was the assistant operating manager of National Boat Carriers also he's the assistant operating manager of Transea and of Seatankers which is a respondent in this case, so that these American corporations are closely related in Seatankers.
Seatankers was the agency which selected the Nikolos to use in this trade.
And necessarily, we hope that the economic pressure which we used could influence Seatankers, perhaps, to change its mind.

And certainly if the only reason for employment of a foreign ship is that the wages, hours and conditions on that ship, are one-fifth of those on American ship, but that reason disappears and American ship would be used, so that the conditions on the Nikolos were important with the union.
They existed as conditions.
The conditions work that the wages were one-fifth of those on these American ship.
But this was a fact which existed when Seatankers procured the Nikolos to enter the salt trade.
So that that is the nature of the dispute and we think that the Norris-LaGuardia Act should apply to it.

There are other problems Mr. Mosser suggested that if we picketed a railroad company that that might be within the protection of the Norris-LaGuardia Act, but obviously it would not, because the industry would be different.
The trade, craft and occupation would be different.
We would not be in the same industry.
It would be a different industry and Norris-LaGuardia would not apply.

We think that a case more closely analogous would be a case in which, for example, in American Longshore Union would picket in a -- in American port to protest the use of foreign non union longshoremen on the -- American joined the foreign ship unloading the ship.

Or if, for example, an American shipowner during the course of a maritime strike, should use a foreign registered vessel, which he might even know in a trade which had been occupied by the struck ships so as to break the strike.

Or, if an American shipowner and there are some operating foreign ships under American contract, should have the termination of the contract say, I won't bargain any further and the union would be told of -- if you put up a picket line and try to strike, the Norris-LaGuardia Act will not prevent an injunction at the behest of the American shipowner.
We think those are cases more closely analogous to the present one.

Now, there was one question asked by Mr. Justice Whittaker the other day with respect to the possibility that on this foreign ship, it might be considered a little piece of Liberia in the port of Tacoma.
That problem was dealt with in the case of Scharrenberg against the Dollar Steamship Company, in which Mr. Justice Clark wrote the opinion of the Court.
That's at 245 U.S. 122 at page 127, decided in 1917.

Mr. Justice Clark said this, “It is, of course, true that for the purposes of jurisdiction a ship, even on the high seas as often said to be a part of the territory of the nation whose flag it flies.”
But in the physical sense, this expression is obviously figurative.

Quoting, International Law Digest, Moore, vol. I Section 174, “And to expand the doctrine to the extent of treating seamen employed on such a ship as working in the country of its registry is quite impossible.”
And the case was quoted with approval by this Court in the Cunard Steamship Company case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: With reference, what was involved in that case, Mr. Jennings?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: That was a case, Your Honor, in which it was maintained that the employment of a foreign seaman on an American vessel in a foreign port constituted use of foreign labor importation of foreign labor into this country in violation of the statute forbidding it.
The Chinese seaman had been employed on --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he was an American citizen.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Pardon Your Honor?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was the seaman an American citizen?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: He was a Chinese citizen.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Chinese citizen.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: He was employed under an American ship in a foreign port.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The question was whether the law applied in American --

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Whether that amounted to employment in American territory because the ship was to be treated as American as an extension of American sovereignty.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And they held not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: And this Court said not.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Are many cases -- doesn't the Harrisburg hold the crime committed in the port of New York confined vessel is one committed on foreign island or foreign lands, foreign territory?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: I think not, Your Honor.

The -- the courts have uniformly recognized that the sovereign of the territory in which the ship is even though it be a foreign ship, may exercise jurisdiction, but as a matter of comity, they normally do not, if it involves inner -- internal relations, relations between the -- the members of the crew and the foreign government.
So the result is if it's a minor crime, normally, we do not exercise jurisdiction.
If it's a major crime, we do.
And for example, the Prohibition Act was applied to foreign ships when they entered American Courts.
That was the Cunard case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Jennings, don't you think we have enough problems on this case without getting into that?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: I think so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Tangled territory of the criminal liability with regard to ships?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: I wanted to answer Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, I appreciate all the information, but I just wonder when you thought we have to decide that too.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor.

In conclusion and we think that the Benz case in this Court, which I think is a case relied on principally by Mr. Mosser, is not controlling in this litigation that the Norris-LaGuardia Act does apply and that the injunction was improvidently granted.

We urge also that in any event, the jurisdiction did not exist below and I wanted to point out that the Court of Appeals believed that the respondents here were not relying upon Section 13 -- 1333 because it is stated in the majority opinion at page 143, “Appellee," that is a respondent here, "has also refrained from invoking jurisdiction on the admiralty side under 28 U.S.C. 1333."

This position may have been dictated by the inability -- unavailability of a jury trial on the damages in the admiralty and because of appellee's belief that admiralty cannot afford injunctive relief so that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, if -- may I ask you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: -- the Court felt that they were not relying on Section 1333.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is your position that this isn't within admiralty jurisdiction of the Court, admiralty is incapacitated from granting the injunction?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
Our position is that, if this be a maritime tort at all and we don't think it has been --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: -- established that it is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
Go on.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: If it be a maritime tort, it is within the exclusive jurisdiction of admiralty and that in that event, the choice is either to sue an admiralty in which event, there is no injunction or to sue one at savings clause in the state court where you may procure an injunction.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, didn't -- and my question was whether -- because admiralty -- it isn't within admiralty.
Of course, one starts that there must be a substantive offense.
The injunction is a remedy, but you say assuming it is an admiralty clause, start with that --

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- then why is it not admiralty because admiralty can't issue an injunction, was it?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: It is in admiralty, Your Honor, but the remedy of injunction is unavailable.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that -- yes, it is an admiralty --

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and since admiralty can't issue an injunction, admiralty has no power in the premises.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Admiralty would have no power.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And since it is admiralty, although it can't accord relief, you can't go on the law of equity side.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Jennings, I -- I notice from your -- your conclusion in your brief that you -- you asked in the event, we decide in your favor that the action be dismissed.
Does that mean that we -- we should reach both jurisdictional questions here?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: I think not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: After we do that?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: That was because, as we explained in our brief, we felt if the Norris-LaGuardia Act applies in the conduct of the -- the union in picketing, it was protected by the provisions of the Clayton Act and therefore, it was perfectly lawful.
That was the reason.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean to say that everything as to which no injunction could be issued is protected?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: No, Your Honor, only the conduct of the union here which was only peaceful patrolling and no more than that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
I understand that, but I don't see what the relevance of the limitation of the Norris-LaGuardia Act has to do with it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I thought your answer to Chief Justice Warren that if the Norris-LaGuardia Act applies, then it's protected.
Is that -- is that what you say?

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: I -- I would say that it is protected by the language of Section 104 (e).

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, not because you can't get an injunction in the federal court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Not because you can't get an injunction.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.
I (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_paul_jennings
turn.label: Mr. John Paul Jennings
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
